Congress found that after the attack on Pearl Harbor, Japanese-Americans in the military were discharged, segregated, and ordered to report to assembly centers for relocation. The Hawaii Provisional Infantry Battalion, consisting of Americans of Japanese ancestry, was sent to Oakland, CA, where the 100th Infantry Battalion was activated in June 1942. The 100th Infantry Battalion's training record and petitions from influential figures led to the re-opening of military service to Nisei volunteers, who joined the 442nd Regimental Combat Team in February 1943. The 100th Infantry Battalion was then moved to Camp Shelby, Mississippi, for further training before being refused deployment by General Eisenhower. The 100th Infantry Battalion, initially refused deployment by General Eisenhower, later trained at Camp Shelby and entered combat in Italy in September 1943. Their bravery led to 6 Distinguished Service Cross awards in the first 8 weeks of combat. They fought at Cassino and Anzio, and later joined forces with the 442nd Regimental Combat Team to push the German Army north of Rome in 1944. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDAL. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for a gold medal to be awarded to the 100th Infantry Battalion and the 442nd Regimental Combat Team for their service in World War II. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal, and it will be displayed at the Smithsonian Institution after the award ceremony. The gold medal awarded to the 100th Infantry Battalion and the 442nd Regimental Combat Team will be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display and research. Congress suggests that the medal should also be displayed at other locations associated with the units. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze, with proceeds deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. The medals are considered national medals, and an amount not exceeding $30,000 is authorized for the cost of the medal.
